(59) 155/(Jr/i October, 1959 DRAFT OPENING speech my Lords and Members of the House of commons.' I am glad that My dear Husband is to make a short visit to Ghana next month and I hope that the visit which we had planned together may be made in1961. .2. The warm and friendly welcome accorded to My Cousin, the princess Alexandra, by the Government and people of Australia has given megreat joy; and I have learned wkh pleasure of the generous courtesy with whichHis Majesty The King of Thailand and His Majesty The King of Cambodia havereceived her in their countries.3. I look forward with pleasure to the visit which the President of the french republic and Mme. de Gauile are to pay to this country next year.4. My Government will work in the closest collaboration with theGovernments of the Commonwealth in all matters which contribute "to peace. Theywill seek to add to the material resources on which the standard of living of the peoples of the Commonwealth must depend and will cherish the spiritual valueswhich form our common heritage.5. The Commonwealth Education Conference which met last July made anumber of recommendations designed to spread the benefits of education more widely within the Commonwealth. The consequential legislation will be laidbefore you.6. I confidently expect that a formal request will be received from the nigerian Legislature for the grant ol independence within the commonwealth to the Federation of Nigeria in 1960. My Government intend to proceed with theappointment of an Advisory Commission in preparation for Ihe review of theconstitution of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland which is to take placenext year. My Government welcome the prospect of the establishment of theRepublic of Cyprus, in accordance with the Agreements concluded at the london conference.7. My Government will continue to work for the improvement of relationsbetween East and West. They will play their full part in the [meetings which they hope to see arranged between Heads of Government] [meeting between Heads of governments which has been arranged for....................................].8. My Government look forward to taking part in the work of the new commission of ten nations which is to consider comprehensive disarmament. Theywill maintain their efforts to achieve agreement at the Geneva Conference on the discontinuance of nuclear weapons' tests., They will persist in their support ofthe United Nations and will seek to increase its influence. They will play their full part in maintaining the North Atlantic Alliance and other regional pacts to whichthey belong. My Armed Forces will continue to make their contribution to thepreservation of peace throughout the world.9. The improvement of conditions of life in the less developed countries of the world will remain an urgent concern of My Government. They will promoteeconomic co-operation between the nations and support plans for financial andtechnical assistance. They have entered into negotiations for setting up a free trade association of seven countries in Europe, and intend that this should assist in theestablishment of wider European trading arrangements which will be in the best interests of the Commonwealth and of the world as a whole.Members of the House of Commons10. Estimates for the public services will be laid before you in due course.My Lords and Members of the House of Commons11. My Ministers will strive to maintain full employment, together withsteady prices, a favourable balance of payments and a continuing improvement in standards of living based on increasing production and a rising rate of investment. - 2 - TOPrSEpRET12. My Government are resolved to harness and develop the resources of science. To this end they entrusted a Cabinet Minister with the task ofco-ordinating and promoting development in research and other scientific activity.13. The problem of local unemployment [whether in Scotland or in Wales orin other parts of the United Kingdpm] will engage the urgent attention of MyGovernmentTand a Bill will be introduced to'deal with this on a new basis and toreplace the Distribution of Industry Acts.14. In order to develop a sound system of communications throughout thecountry, My Government will press forward with their policy of building newhighways and improving existing roads:' They will encourage further modernisation of the railways and will devote special attention to the future of the aircraft industry.Proposals will be laid before you for the licensing of air services and of airlineoperators. These will be designed to give a greater measure of freedom to thenational and independent companies and to ensure the maintenance of high standards of safety.15. My Government will examine the working of the Companies Act and will introduce a bill to strengthen the present law relating to building societies. [Theywill put before you also legislation to amend the law on weights and measures andto permit the payment of wages through a bank to any employee who so requests.]16. The well-being of all those whose living depends on the land will remainone of the first cares of My Government. The system of guaranteed prices andthe long-term assurances in the Agriculture Act of 1957 will be continued.Legislation will be introduced to provide grants for horticultural growers and.My Government will encourage the more economic marketing of produce. Inparticular, proposals will be put before you for reorganising and improvingCovent Garden Market.17. Proposals will be put before you also to continue the subsidies and grantsgiven to the fishing industry and to make further provision for co-operation in international measures of conservation. At the Second World Conference onthe Law of the Sea, to be held next spring, My Ministers will work for a just and reasonable settlement of the unresolved problems of the breadth of the territorial sea and of fishery limits.18. My Government will give close attention to the social welfare of my people. The needs of old people and of the war-disabled and their dependantswill remain the subject of especial care; the rates of benefit and contribution underthe National Insurance Scheme will be kept under review; and the earnings rules for pensioners and widowed mothers will be further relaxed. New house building will be maintained at a high level and the slum clearance campaign will continue.Legislation will be introduced to modernise the law on mental health and onsuccession in Scotland. A Bill will also be laid before you providing for the registration of certain professions auxiliary to medicine.19. The special needs of the young in the society of to-day are of profoundinterest to My Ministers. They will press on with their plans to improve school buildings and to achieve enlarged opportunities not only in the secondary schoolsbut also in the technical colleges and the universities. Their plans to enable moreteachers to be trained will help to reduce the size of classes. They will take stepsto secure that the number of trained youth leaders is increased and that throughthe Youth Service and in other ways young people are enabled to put their leisureto better use in a variety of activities, whether in sport, the arts or other recreation.20. My Government will introduce a new measure to provide more effective means of dealing with young offenders and also to extend compulsory after-care to prisoners who, by supervision on discharge, may be prevented from revertingto crime. Further advances will be made in penal reform and the rebuilding of ourprisons. Legislation will be introduced to amend and modernise the law onbetting and gaming and to make legal aid and advice more widely available.A Bill will be prepared to bring up-to-date the various statutes relating toCharitable Trusts.21. Other measures will be laid before you in due course.My Lords and Members of the House of Commons22. I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels.TOP SECRET
